title: Zhuhai Municipal Government grants NZ $114,000 to Cook Island's government for fisheries equipment
description: On August 1st, 2017, a formal handover ceremony was held for the Zhuhai Municipal Government, which granted equipment to the Fisheries Equipment and Training Project (or Fisheries Support Project). Zhuhai City government is the project implementer, and the funds were handed over to the Cook Islands Ministry of Marine Resources. The total grant is worth NZ $114,000 (USD $82,000). The agreement was signed in September 2016, when a delegation from the Cook Islands visited Zhuhai in Guangzhou, China, to discuss cooperation on agriculture, fisheries, culture, tourism, and health. As part of this agreement, Zhuhai City pledged a donation of equipment worth $US82,000 to support marine surveillance in the Cook Islands. This part of the agreement was fulfilled in August 2017 when a delegation from Zhuhai City presented the Cook Island’s government with equipment including 6 First Aid Kits, 9 Go Pro Hero4 Session Cameras, 2 2016 Nissan Navara Trucks, 2 2016 Honda Wave 110CC, 4 HP Elite Display Series E242 Monitors, 6 EPIRB/PLB units (Mapworld Ltd), 3 GPS Units (Mapworld Ltd), 6 ln Reach Devices (Mapworld Ltd), 1 DSLR Camera. These goods were locally sourced (not from China) to help the local economy. The agreement also includes training for the Ministry of Marine Resources and Ministry of Agriculture officials in China. The group will be trained in aquaculture, growing tropical fruits, and other tropical plantings. If successful, phase two of this project will involve experts from Zhuhai visiting the Cook Islands for more training. This project was initiated and completed in 2017. No training info has been found.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Zhuhai Municipal Government grants NZ $114,000 to Cook Island's government for fisheries equipment

# Description
On August 1st, 2017, a formal handover ceremony was held for the Zhuhai Municipal Government, which granted equipment to the Fisheries Equipment and Training Project (or Fisheries Support Project). Zhuhai City government is the project implementer, and the funds were handed over to the Cook Islands Ministry of Marine Resources. The total grant is worth NZ $114,000 (USD $82,000). The agreement was signed in September 2016, when a delegation from the Cook Islands visited Zhuhai in Guangzhou, China, to discuss cooperation on agriculture, fisheries, culture, tourism, and health. As part of this agreement, Zhuhai City pledged a donation of equipment worth $US82,000 to support marine surveillance in the Cook Islands. This part of the agreement was fulfilled in August 2017 when a delegation from Zhuhai City presented the Cook Island’s government with equipment including 6 First Aid Kits, 9 Go Pro Hero4 Session Cameras, 2 2016 Nissan Navara Trucks, 2 2016 Honda Wave 110CC, 4 HP Elite Display Series E242 Monitors, 6 EPIRB/PLB units (Mapworld Ltd), 3 GPS Units (Mapworld Ltd), 6 ln Reach Devices (Mapworld Ltd), 1 DSLR Camera. These goods were locally sourced (not from China) to help the local economy. The agreement also includes training for the Ministry of Marine Resources and Ministry of Agriculture officials in China. The group will be trained in aquaculture, growing tropical fruits, and other tropical plantings. If successful, phase two of this project will involve experts from Zhuhai visiting the Cook Islands for more training. This project was initiated and completed in 2017. No training info has been found.
justification: Project focuses on fisheries equipment donation and training, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of equipment for marine surveillance, training in aquaculture and agriculture, focus on capacity building

title: China donates two Y12E aircraft to Costa Rica
description: On October 18, 2016, the Aviation Industries of China (AVIC) delivered two Y12E aircraft to the Government of Costa Rica to support its security forces at the Omar Santamaria International Airport in San Jose. An official presentation of the aircraft occurred on October 24, 2016. The two planes are for the Aerial Surveillance Service's (SVA) fleet and will be used for special missions such as coastal patrol, air rescues, and combating organized crime and drug trafficking. SVA and the Costa Rica Ministry of Public Security completed the administrative admission process. Technical services on the aircraft were completed in October 2017, and the handover certificate from the People's Republic of China to the Government of Costa Rica was signed on November 1, 2017. The total cost of the aircraft is unknown; the media source Infodefensa estimates that the grant was worth about USD $12 million, while Elmundo estimates that the grant was worth USD $18 million.   Through this project, a delegation of four pilots and six aviation mechanics from the SVA fleet were also trained for six weeks in China to pilot, maintain, and repair these aircraft.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates two Y12E aircraft to Costa Rica

# Description
On October 18, 2016, the Aviation Industries of China (AVIC) delivered two Y12E aircraft to the Government of Costa Rica to support its security forces at the Omar Santamaria International Airport in San Jose. An official presentation of the aircraft occurred on October 24, 2016. The two planes are for the Aerial Surveillance Service's (SVA) fleet and will be used for special missions such as coastal patrol, air rescues, and combating organized crime and drug trafficking. SVA and the Costa Rica Ministry of Public Security completed the administrative admission process. Technical services on the aircraft were completed in October 2017, and the handover certificate from the People's Republic of China to the Government of Costa Rica was signed on November 1, 2017. The total cost of the aircraft is unknown; the media source Infodefensa estimates that the grant was worth about USD $12 million, while Elmundo estimates that the grant was worth USD $18 million.   Through this project, a delegation of four pilots and six aviation mechanics from the SVA fleet were also trained for six weeks in China to pilot, maintain, and repair these aircraft.
justification: Aircraft donation for security and public safety purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Aircraft for coastal patrol, air rescues, and combating organized crime; includes training for pilots and mechanics

title: China Eximbank provides $57.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase 1 of Video Surveillance Platform Project (Linked to Project ID#92204, ID#92205, and ID#92206)
description: On June 6, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Côte d'Ivoire signed a $57,107,286.55 (CFA 27,790,839,066.10) preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC No. (2016) 4 TOTAL NO. (392)] for Phase 1 of the Video Surveillance Platform Project. It was ratified by the Government of Cote d'Ivoire on August 31, 2016. The borrowing terms of the PBC are unknown. However, it is known that the proceeds of the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a commercial contract with Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd.   As of April 2022, the loan had achieved a 117.3% disbursement rate (CFA 32,608,412,922 out of CFA 27,790,839,066.10). 6 disbursements (worth CFA 32,608,412,922) took place between 2017 and 2020: a CFA 5,899,456,283 disbursement on December 31, 2017, a CFA 12,311,081,310 disbursement on July 31, 2018, a CFA 4,973,823,456 disbursement on November 30, 2018, a CFA 4,609,394,849 disbursement on April 30, 2019, a CFA 2,227,192,738 disbursement on September 30, 2019, and a CFA 2,587,464,286 on March 31, 2020.   This project involved the laying of 270 kilometers of fiber optic cable and the installation of 1,000 video surveillance cameras in the capital city of the Abidjan. It also sought to connect these cameras to a traffic monitoring system using license plate readers and variable message signs for the detection of red light violations. The ultimate objectives of the project were to reduce crime, establish an infrastructure monitoring system, and establish a road traffic regulation and control system in ten areas: Abobo, Adjame, Attécoubé, Cocody, Koumassi, Marcory, Plateau, Port-Bouet, Treichville, Yopougon.   Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. This project commenced in 2017. As of January 2019, 91% of the cameras were installed; 95% of the operation centers were established; 75% for the management of road and traffic monitoring equipment was installed; and 85% coverage for fiber optic cable was installed. The project was expected to reach completion in March-April 2019. It was ultimately completed on February 28, 2021.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Abidjan Safe City Project and the Video Protection Platform in Abidjan Project. The French project title is Le Projet de plateforme de vidéo protection de la ville d'Abidjan or Le Projet de mise en œuvre de la plate forme unifiée et ouverte de la vidéo protection de la ville d'Abidjan or Le projet de vidéosurveillance de la ville d'Abidjan. The Chinese project title is 阿比让平安城市视频监控系统 or 科特迪瓦平安城市项目 or 阿比让平安城市项目.2. According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the face value of the loan from China Eximbank is considerably higher than the face value reported by other sources. The AMP also records a different loan commitment date (November 30, 2017). The issues warrant further investigation.3. The AMP system identification number for the China Eximbank loan is 1120071316138. The AMP project code for the China Eximbank loan is 251 9201 78. 4. The project coordinator for Phase 1 of the Video Surveillance Platform Project is COLL GUELPETCHIN M. OUATTARA.5. Bank of China also financed the second and third phases of the project (as captured via Project ID#92204, ID#92205, and ID#92206).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $57.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase 1 of Video Surveillance Platform Project (Linked to Project ID#92204, ID#92205, and ID#92206)

# Description
On June 6, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Côte d'Ivoire signed a $57,107,286.55 (CFA 27,790,839,066.10) preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC No. (2016) 4 TOTAL NO. (392)] for Phase 1 of the Video Surveillance Platform Project. It was ratified by the Government of Cote d'Ivoire on August 31, 2016. The borrowing terms of the PBC are unknown. However, it is known that the proceeds of the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a commercial contract with Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd.   As of April 2022, the loan had achieved a 117.3% disbursement rate (CFA 32,608,412,922 out of CFA 27,790,839,066.10). 6 disbursements (worth CFA 32,608,412,922) took place between 2017 and 2020: a CFA 5,899,456,283 disbursement on December 31, 2017, a CFA 12,311,081,310 disbursement on July 31, 2018, a CFA 4,973,823,456 disbursement on November 30, 2018, a CFA 4,609,394,849 disbursement on April 30, 2019, a CFA 2,227,192,738 disbursement on September 30, 2019, and a CFA 2,587,464,286 on March 31, 2020.   This project involved the laying of 270 kilometers of fiber optic cable and the installation of 1,000 video surveillance cameras in the capital city of the Abidjan. title: Chinese Government funds and conducts 2016 Seminar on Rice Cultivation in Cote d'Ivoire
description: On 29 June 2016, the opening ceremony took place in Abidjan for a seminar on rice cultivation technology (Seminaire 2016 sur les Techniques de la Culture du Riz or 水稻技术培训班). The one-month-long training course was sponsored by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, and co-run by China's Foreign Economic Cooperation Center under their Ministry of Agriculture and Cote d'Ivoire's National Rice Development Office under their Ministry of Agriculture. The seminar was taught by 10 experts from the Chinese Ministry of Agriculture, Hunan Hybrid Rice Research Center, Hunan Agricultural University, and others. The value of this training and number of students are unknown. The graduation ceremony was held on 28 July 2016.  China conducted this course in 2017 (project #65997), 2018 (project #66010), and 2019 (project #71215).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government funds and conducts 2016 Seminar on Rice Cultivation in Cote d'Ivoire

# Description
On 29 June 2016, the opening ceremony took place in Abidjan for a seminar on rice cultivation technology (Seminaire 2016 sur les Techniques de la Culture du Riz or 水稻技术培训班). The one-month-long training course was sponsored by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce, and co-run by China's Foreign Economic Cooperation Center under their Ministry of Agriculture and Cote d'Ivoire's National Rice Development Office under their Ministry of Agriculture. The seminar was taught by 10 experts from the Chinese Ministry of Agriculture, Hunan Hybrid Rice Research Center, Hunan Agricultural University, and others. The value of this training and number of students are unknown. The graduation ceremony was held on 28 July 2016.  China conducted this course in 2017 (project #65997), 2018 (project #66010), and 2019 (project #71215).
justification: Project focuses on agricultural training and knowledge transfer without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Seminar on rice cultivation technology, agricultural training program, knowledge transfer focus

title: 20 Ivorians visit China for Construction and Management training course
description: On 1 September 2016, the Chinese Embassy in Cote d'Ivoire held a farewell ceremony for the 20 Ivorians about to travel to Tianjin, China for the 2016 Development Zone Construction and Management training course occurring between 6 and 26 September. The purpose of this training is to teach and promote industrial parks in Cote d'Ivoire. The program value and who financed and organized it is unknown.

title: Chinese Government donates 9 million CFA to Cote d'Ivoire Red Cross
description: On 7 November 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire officially handed over a check of 9 million CFA to the Ivorian Red Cross. According to a Ministry of Commerce of Cote d'Ivoire article, the funds will be used for a project supporting young mothers in the north of the country.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government donates 9 million CFA to Cote d'Ivoire Red Cross

# Description
On 7 November 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire officially handed over a check of 9 million CFA to the Ivorian Red Cross. According to a Ministry of Commerce of Cote d'Ivoire article, the funds will be used for a project supporting young mothers in the north of the country.
justification: Project involves financial donation for social welfare purposes without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation to Red Cross for supporting young mothers, no energy or infrastructure components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Phase 2 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#66425, ID#87873, ID#92286)
description: In 2009, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided an RMB 49.98 million (CFA 4 billion) grant to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire for the Gagnoa General Hospital Construction Project. The grant proceeds covered 100% of the commercial contract cost but the Government of Cote d'Ivoire also contributed CFA 2 billion.  This project involved the construction of a hospital in Gagnoa, which is the hometown of President Gbagbo. The 104-bed hospital is 6,531 square meters and it has departments for internal medicine, surgery, pediatrics, gynecology, medical imaging, laboratory analysis, and administration. Wuhan Architectural Design Institute was the contractor responsible for project design, and Gansu Geo-Engineering Co. Ltd (甘肃海外工程总公司) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  On April 4, 2009, a foundation-laying ceremony took place. Construction took place between April 18, 2009 and August 31, 2010. Then, on November 25, 2011, the project was officially completed and handed over to the Ivorian authorities. The handover ceremony was delayed due to a presidential election crisis in Cote d'Ivoire. The hospital was officially inaugurated on March 4, 2013.   The Chinese Government then funded three technical assistance projects between 2013 and 2019 to support the maintenance and operations of this hospital. On July 5, 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed a CFA 640,625,000 grant agreement for Phase 1 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (captured via Project ID#92286). According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), Phase 1 was implemented between July 5, 2013 and July 4, 2015. The Chinese Government disbursed CFA 635,129,402.87 of grant funding in support of Phase 1 on June 30, 2014.   Then, in August 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed letters of exchange regarding Phase 2 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (captured via Project ID#66030). The monetary value of the grant commitment that supported Phase 2 is unknown. A Phase 2 completion ceremony was held on December 3, 2018.   Then, on October 17, 2019, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed a grant agreement for Phase 3 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (captured via Project ID#87873). The monetary value of the grant commitment that supported Phase 3 is unknown.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as Phase 2 of the Gagnoa Hospital Maintenance Project. The French project title is 2ème phase d'assistance technique pour l'hôpital de Gagnoa. The Chinese project title is 加尼瓦医院第二期技术合作项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Phase 2 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#66425, ID#87873, ID#92286)

# Description
In 2009, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided an RMB 49.98 million (CFA 4 billion) grant to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire for the Gagnoa General Hospital Construction Project. The grant proceeds covered 100% of the commercial contract cost but the Government of Cote d'Ivoire also contributed CFA 2 billion.  This project involved the construction of a hospital in Gagnoa, which is the hometown of President Gbagbo. The 104-bed hospital is 6,531 square meters and it has departments for internal medicine, surgery, pediatrics, gynecology, medical imaging, laboratory analysis, and administration. Wuhan Architectural Design Institute was the contractor responsible for project design, and Gansu Geo-Engineering Co. Ltd (甘肃海外工程总公司) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  On April 4, 2009, a foundation-laying ceremony took place. Construction took place between April 18, 2009 and August 31, 2010. Then, on November 25, 2011, the project was officially completed and handed over to the Ivorian authorities. The handover ceremony was delayed due to a presidential election crisis in Cote d'Ivoire. The hospital was officially inaugurated on March 4, 2013.   The Chinese Government then funded three technical assistance projects between 2013 and 2019 to support the maintenance and operations of this hospital. On July 5, 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed a CFA 640,625,000 grant agreement for Phase 1 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (captured via Project ID#92286). According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), Phase 1 was implemented between July 5, 2013 and July 4, 2015. The Chinese Government disbursed CFA 635,129,402.87 of grant funding in support of Phase 1 on June 30, 2014.   Then, in August 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed letters of exchange regarding Phase 2 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (captured via Project ID#66030). The monetary value of the grant commitment that supported Phase 2 is unknown. A Phase 2 completion ceremony was held on December 3, 2018.   Then, on October 17, 2019, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed a grant agreement for Phase 3 of the Gagnoa Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (captured via Project ID#87873). The monetary value of the grant commitment that supported Phase 3 is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on hospital construction and technical cooperation, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 104-bed hospital, technical assistance for maintenance and operations, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides CFA 20.69 billion interest-free loan for Ebimpé Olympic Stadium Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#53269, #85370)
description: On November 4, 2014, China’s Ministry of Commerce and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an RMB 300 million (CFA 25,710,000,000) interest-free loan agreement for the Ebimpé Olympic Stadium Construction Project. This loan carries the following borrowing terms: a 25-year maturity, a 15-year grace-period, and a 0% interest rate. It is scheduled for repayment between December 1, 2029 and November 30, 2039. In addition to this loan, this stadium project was financed by an additional grant and interest-free loan from the Chinese Government:   (1) a CFA 11.9 billion grant provided in March 2017 (captured via Project ID#85370), and  (2) a CFA 20.69 million interest-free loan issued on February 22, 2016 (captured via Project ID#73441).   The loan and grant proceeds were to be used to finance an RMB 750,000,000 (CFA 63,990,243,240) commercial contract [ID#2016-0-2-1417/02-29 between Ivorian Government and Beijing Construction Engineering Group (BCEG), which was signed on July 22, 2016. The Ivorian Government was responsible for providing CFA 4 billion of counterpart financing for earthworks and the installation of water, electrical and telecommunications infrastructure at the project site.  This project involved the construction of a 60,012 seat stadium in Ebimpé within the Anyama sub-prefecture. It also involved the construction of an Olympic village surrounding the stadium, which has 4 housing estates, a training complex, administrative buildings, a commercial area, a clinic, a 4-star hotel, a 9-hole golf course, and of a medium voltage power line (15 kV) dedicated to the stadium (from the Yopougon 2 HV/MV transformer station to the industrial zone). Additionally, it involved the construction of a 10,000 seat multi-purpose arena.   Beijing Construction Engineering Group (BCEG) was the contractor responsible for implementation. It hired approximately 1000 workers, of which 350 were Chinese and 650 were Ivorian. Project implementation commenced on December 10, 2016. Then, a groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 22, 2016 (originally planned for January 2016). Shortly thereafter, on December 31, 2016, the Chinese Government made a loan disbursement worth CFA 14 billion. An electrical connection for the project site was established on August 18, 2017.  Foundation pile construction was completed on September 26, 2017. Construction was expected to last 24 months and project was originally expected to reach completion on October 21, 2019.When the Ivorian Minister of Sports inspected the construction site in August 2018, the project had achieved a 50% completion rate and its expected completion (delivery) date had been pushed back to November 21, 2019.  An opening ceremony for the stadium took place on October 3, 2020. It was completed in advance of the the 2021 Africa Cup of Nations football (soccer) tournament. According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the project encountered several problems during implementation, including ‘bad behavior’ among Chinese team leaders towards the workers on the project site, a lack of protective equipment for workers, a worker strike on October 23, 2017 for better wages and improved working conditions, and non-compliance with the contractual deadlines for the execution of the project.
staff_comments: 1. This stadium is also known as the Alassane Ouattara Olympic Stadium (Stade Olympique Alassane Ouattara). 2. The Chinese project title is 科特迪瓦阿比让体育场项目 or 艾宾贝奥林匹克体育场施. The French project title is Projet du stade Olympique d'Ebimpé. 3. The RMB 300 million loan agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/rwpk51m9id49llw/EBIMPE%20-ACCORD%20CI%20GOUV%20CHINE.pdf?dl=0. 4. The AMP system identification number for the RMB 300 million loan is 11200713583. The AMP project code is 78081000181.5. No sources explicitly state that the face value of the loan issued on February 22, 2016 was CFA 20.69 billion. According to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government provided CFA 67,319,989,326 (or approximately RMB 714.6 million) in total funding for this project. Therefore, AidData assumes that the face value of the interest-free loan contracted on February 22, 2016 is equivalent to the difference (CFA 20.69 billion) between that aggregate amount (CFA 67.3 billion) and the sum of the November 2014 loan amount (CFA 25.71 billion or RMB 300 million) of the March 2017 grant amount (CFA 11.9 billion). However, it is possible that the value of the interest-free loan is slightly higher than CFA 20.69 billion. The AMP includes another record (system ID#1120071337612) for a CFA 25,716,072,291.99 loan, which was issued on November 4, 2014, for a project called ‘Projet de construction de stade à Abidjan’. This issue warrants further investigation. 6. Since the borrowing terms of the CFA 20.69 billion interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set maturity period to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity period of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace. 7. Ebimpé Olympic Stadium is a circular building built on a rectangular plot of 20 hectares (200,000 m²). It consists of five levels with a main reinforced concrete structure and a membrane structure cover, supported by a lattice steel frame.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides CFA 20.69 billion interest-free loan for Ebimpé Olympic Stadium Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#53269, #85370)

# Description
On November 4, 2014, China’s Ministry of Commerce and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire signed an RMB 300 million (CFA 25,710,000,000) interest-free loan agreement for the Ebimpé Olympic Stadium Construction Project. This loan carries the following borrowing terms: a 25-year maturity, a 15-year grace-period, and a 0% interest rate. It is scheduled for repayment between December 1, 2029 and November 30, 2039. In addition to this loan, this stadium project was financed by an additional grant and interest-free loan from the Chinese Government:   (1) a CFA 11.9 billion grant provided in March 2017 (captured via Project ID#85370), and  (2) a CFA 20.69 million interest-free loan issued on February 22, 2016 (captured via Project ID#73441).   The loan and grant proceeds were to be used to finance an RMB 750,000,000 (CFA 63,990,243,240) commercial contract [ID#2016-0-2-1417/02-29 between Ivorian Government and Beijing Construction Engineering Group (BCEG), which was signed on July 22, 2016. The Ivorian Government was responsible for providing CFA 4 billion of counterpart financing for earthworks and the installation of water, electrical and telecommunications infrastructure at the project site.  This project involved the construction of a 60,012 seat stadium in Ebimpé within the Anyama sub-prefecture. It also involved the construction of an Olympic village surrounding the stadium, which has 4 housing estates, a training complex, administrative buildings, a commercial area, a clinic, a 4-star hotel, a 9-hole golf course, and of a medium voltage power line (15 kV) dedicated to the stadium (from the Yopougon 2 HV/MV transformer station to the industrial zone). Additionally, it involved the construction of a 10,000 seat multi-purpose arena.   Beijing Construction Engineering Group (BCEG) was the contractor responsible for implementation. It hired approximately 1000 workers, of which 350 were Chinese and 650 were Ivorian. Project implementation commenced on December 10, 2016. Then, a groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 22, 2016 (originally planned for January 2016). Shortly thereafter, on December 31, 2016, the Chinese Government made a loan disbursement worth CFA 14 billion. An electrical connection for the project site was established on August 18, 2017.  Foundation pile construction was completed on September 26, 2017. Construction was expected to last 24 months and project was originally expected to reach completion on October 21, 2019.When the Ivorian Minister of Sports inspected the construction site in August 2018, the project had achieved a 50% completion rate and its expected completion (delivery) date had been pushed back to November 21, 2019.  An opening ceremony for the stadium took place on October 3, 2020. It was completed in advance of the the 2021 Africa Cup of Nations football (soccer) tournament. According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the project encountered several problems during implementation, including ‘bad behavior’ among Chinese team leaders towards the workers on the project site, a lack of protective equipment for workers, a worker strike on October 23, 2017 for better wages and improved working conditions, and non-compliance with the contractual deadlines for the execution of the project.
justification: Project primarily involves construction of sports infrastructure and related facilities without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of Olympic stadium, housing estates, training complex, commercial area, clinic, hotel, and golf course - all primarily social infrastructure

title: Chinese Government provides $2.83 billion of debt forgiveness in 2016 (Linked to Project ID#39195)
description: In 2016, the Chinese Government reportedly forgave 42.7% ($2.83 billion) of the Cuban's Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $6 billion). The Chinese Government reportedly rescheduled the remaining 52.8% of the the Cuban Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $3.17 billion). The exact terms of the restructuring are unknown. However, one source suggests that 5 years of additional grace was provided as well as an interest rate reduction.
staff_comments: 1. The Cuban Government's 2016 debt cancellation agreement with the Chinese Government came shortly after the Cuban Government rescheduled its debts with Paris Club creditors in December 2015. The 2015 Paris Club agreement with the Cuban Government, seen by Reuters, forgave $8.5 billion of the Cuban Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $11.1 billion). These obligations resulted from debts that the Cuban Government defaulted on in 1986, plus charges. Under the terms of the 2015 agreement, repayment of the outstanding debt in annual installments was back loaded through 2033. In exchange, the Cuban Government agreed to pay the remaining principal ($2.6 billion) that it owed Paris Club creditors since its 1986 default over an 18-year period. The Paris Club is an informal group of creditor governments from Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Russia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United States. 2. As of October 2020, Recardo Cabrisas (Ricardo Cabrisas) was Cuba's chief debt negotiator. 3. Given that most if not all of the loans that the Chinese Government issued to the Cuban Government between 2000 and 2016 had not reached their maturity dates at the time that this act of debt forgiveness took place, there is a low level of risk that the loans forgiven are captured as separate transactions in AidData's dataset. As such, the risk of double counting is low and AidData has not assigned the transaction to the umbrella category. However, this issue warrants further investigation.4. The Chinese Government's 2011 debt restructuring of Cuban debt is captured via Project ID#39195.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government provides $2.83 billion of debt forgiveness in 2016 (Linked to Project ID#39195)

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Government reportedly forgave 42.7% ($2.83 billion) of the Cuban's Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $6 billion). The Chinese Government reportedly rescheduled the remaining 52.8% of the the Cuban Government's outstanding debt obligations (worth $3.17 billion). The exact terms of the restructuring are unknown. However, one source suggests that 5 years of additional grace was provided as well as an interest rate reduction.
justification: Debt restructuring and forgiveness is a financial service without direct environmental impact
evidence: Debt forgiveness and restructuring of $2.83 billion, no specific project or environmental impact mentioned
